head.title: Israel Has Controlled Little of Palestine

hedline.hl1: Israel Has Controlled Little of Palestine

block.p: In "Palestinians Have Reason to Take Heart" (Op-Ed, Sept. 3), Rami G. Khouri writes that the Gaza-Jericho autonomy plan for the Arabs "represents the first . . . rollback of the 20th century's Zionist-Israeli domination of Palestine."

In "Palestinians Have Reason to Take Heart" (Op-Ed, Sept. 3), Rami G. Khouri writes that the Gaza-Jericho autonomy plan for the Arabs "represents the first . . . rollback of the 20th century's Zionist-Israeli domination of Palestine."

It is a historical falsehood to state that "Zionist Israelis" have dominated Palestine in this century. From 1900 to 1917 the Turkish Ottoman Empire had control over Palestine. After World War I, the British were given the mandate over Palestine. In 1922 Britain gave that portion of Palestine east of the Jordan River to the Arab King Abdullah and called it "Transjordan," which consisted of 78 percent of Palestine until 1947.

At that time, United Nations Resolution 181 offered a partition of the area into an Arab and a Jewish state. The Arabs rejected this partition and went to war against Israel. Jordan (formerly Transjordan) seized the West Bank and East Jerusalem, while Egypt seized Gaza. Therefore, Israel was left with 12 percent of original Palestine.
During the defensive war of 1967, Israel captured the West Bank and Gaza, which gave Israel control over 22 percent of the original mandate of Palestine until today.

If Israel relinquishes its religious, historic and security rights to portions of these territories to the Arabs, Israel will once again control only 12 percent of Palestine. Therefore only between 1967 and 1993 would Israel have controlled even 22 percent of Palestine. MORTON A. KLEIN President Greater Philadelphia Chapter Zionist Organization of America Philadelphia, Sept. 5, 1993
